stem: The patient is experiencing autonomic dysreflexia. Based on the information presented in the patient's chart, complete the following actions to manage this complication. Drag the nursing interventions to the appropriate section to indicate the order in which you would implement them. Not all actions will be used. Use each action ONLY ONCE.

itemContext.sbar:
S: Mr. Smith, a 35-year-old male with a T6 spinal cord injury sustained 3 years ago, is reporting a severe headache and feeling flushed. 
B: The patient has a history of autonomic dysreflexia. His baseline BP is around 110/70. He has been continent of bowel and bladder with a scheduled intermittent catheterization every 6 hours and a daily bowel program. Last catheterization was at 06:00, yielding 300 mL clear yellow urine. Bowel program is scheduled for 18:00.
A: At 14:15, his BP is 190/110, and HR is 55. He is diaphoretic above the level of injury. I suspect autonomic dysreflexia. He denies bladder distention or fecal impaction but states he is having some lower abdominal cramping. The skin is intact around the catheter insertion site.
R: I recommend immediate intervention for autonomic dysreflexia, including checking for bladder distention/kinking of the catheter, administering antihypertensive medication if BP remains elevated, and notifying the physician if symptoms persist or worsen.

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct: The correct order of interventions is: 1. Elevate the head of the bed to 90 degrees. This will help lower the blood pressure by promoting venous pooling. 2. Assess for bladder distention or catheter obstruction, as bladder issues are a common cause of autonomic dysreflexia due to the stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system. 3. Loosen any tight clothing or constrictive devices to remove any external stimuli that may be contributing to the episode. 4. Administer hydralazine 10 mg IV PRN for SBP > 160. This is an antihypertensive medication to help lower the blood pressure quickly by causing vasodilation. 5. Continue to monitor blood pressure every 5 minutes and document findings to evaluate the effectiveness of the interventions.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect actions or incorrect sequencing can lead to delayed treatment and potentially serious complications from uncontrolled hypertension. Failing to address the underlying cause (e.g., bladder distention) will prevent resolution of the autonomic dysreflexia. Administering medication without addressing the cause may only temporarily mask the symptoms and delay proper treatment. Not monitoring BP closely can lead to missing further escalation or lack of response to intervention.
clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency requiring prompt assessment and intervention to prevent severe complications such as stroke or seizure.
Elevating the head of the bed is a quick and easy way to help lower blood pressure by decreasing venous return to the heart.
Always assess for and address the underlying cause of autonomic dysreflexia, as treating the cause is essential for resolving the episode.
Monitor blood pressure closely and document all interventions and patient responses to ensure timely and effective management.

questionTrap.trap: Students may be tempted to immediately administer medication without first assessing for and addressing the underlying cause, which is a common mistake.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Emphasize the importance of the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) and addressing the underlying cause of the problem before administering medication. Prioritize interventions based on immediate threat to patient safety and the need to resolve the root cause of the dysreflexia.

mnemonic.title: SIT UP
mnemonic.expansion: Sit the patient up (HOB to 90 degrees), Investigate the cause, Treat the cause, Usually bladder/bowel related, Pharmacological intervention if needed.
